cleaned_text: Rudolf Steiner Rudolf Steiner |Born| Rudolf Joseph Lorenz Lorenz Steiner (27 or 25 February 1861 [[1]](#cite_note-birth-1) - gained initial recognition at the end of the nineteenth century as a [literary critic](/wiki/Literary_criticism) and published works including [The Philosophy of Freedom](/wiki/The_Philosophy_of_Freedom). [[13]](#cite_note-Cees-13) At the beginning of the twentieth century he founded an esoteric spiritual movement, [anthroposophy](/wiki/Anthroposophy), with roots in [German idealist philosophy](/wiki/German_idealism) and [theosophy](/wiki/Theosophy_(Blavatskian)). His teachings have been that these are neognosticism [[20]](#cite_note-Diener_Hipolito_2013_p._77-20) [[21]](#cite_note-Ellwood_Partin_2016_p.-21)). Many of his ideas are pseudoscientific. [[22]](#cite_note-22) He was also prone to [pseudohistory](/wiki/Pseudohistory). [[23]](#cite_note-Staudenmaier_2014_p.-23) In the first, more philosophically oriented phase of this movement, Steiner attempted to find a synthesis between [science](/wiki/Science) and [spirituality](/wiki/Spirituality). [[24]](#cite_note-24) His philosophical work of these years, which he termed " [spiritual science](/wiki/Spiritual_science)", sought to apply what he saw as the clarity of thinking characteristic of Western philosophy to spiritual questions, [[25]](#cite_note-RAMcD-25): 291 differentiating this approach from what he considered to be vaguer approaches to mysticism. In a second phase, beginning around 1907, he began working collaboratively in a variety of artistic media, including drama, dance and architecture, culminating in the building of the [Goetheanum](/wiki/Goetheanum), a cultural centre to house [all the arts](/wiki/Gesamtkunstwerk). [[26]](#cite_note-26) In the third phase of his work, beginning after [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I), Steiner worked on of [ethical individualism](/wiki/Ethical_individualism), to which he later brought a more explicitly spiritual approach. He based his [epistemology](/wiki/Epistemology) on [Johann Wolfgang Goethe](/wiki/Johann_Wolfgang_Goethe)'s world view, in which "thinking...is no more and no less an organ of perception than the eye or ear. Just as the eye perceives colours and the ear sounds, so thinking perceives ideas." [[29]](#cite_note-29) A consistent thread that runs through his work is the goal of demonstrating that there are no limits to human knowledge. [[30]](#cite_note-30) Biography[ a position a [gamekeeper](/wiki/Gamekeeper) [[31]](#cite_note-31) in the service of Count [Hoyos](/wiki/House_of_Hoyos) in [Geras](/wiki/Geras,_Austria), northeast [Lower Austria](/wiki/Lower_Austria) (1834 [Horn](/wiki/Horn,_Austria) - 1918, Horn), a marriage for which the Count had refused his permission. Johann became a telegraph operator on the Southern Austrian Railway, and at the time of Rudolf's birth was stationed in Murakirály ( [Kraljevec](/wiki/Donji_Kraljevec)) in [Croatia](/wiki/Croatia)). In the first two years of Rudolf's life, the family moved twice, first to [Mödling](/wiki/M%C3%B6dling), near [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna), and then, through the promotion of his father to stationmaster, to [Pottschach](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pottschach), located in the foothills of the eastern Austrian [Alps](/wiki/Alps) in [Lower Austria](/wiki/Lower_Austria). [[27]](#cite_note-CL-27) Steiner entered the village school, but following a disagreement between his father and the schoolmaster, he was briefly educated at home. In 1869, when Steiner was eight years old, the family moved to the village of [Neudörfl](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neud%C3%B6rfl) and in October 1872 Steiner proceeded from the village school there to the [realschule](/wiki/Realschule) in [Wiener Neustadt](/wiki/Wiener_Neustadt). [[2]](#cite_note-Auto-2): Chap. 2 In 1879, the family moved to [Inzersdorf](/wiki/Inzersdorf_(Vienna)) to enable Steiner to attend the [Vienna Institute of Technology](/wiki/TU_Wien), [[32]](#cite_note-32) where enrolled [mathematics](/wiki/Mathematics), [physics](/wiki/Physics), [botany](/wiki/Botany), [zoology](/wiki/Zoology), and [mineralogy](/wiki/Mineralogy) and audited courses [literature](/wiki/Literature) and [philosophy](/wiki/Philosophy), on an academic scholarship from 1879 to 1883, where he completed his studies and the requirements of the Ghega scholarship satisfactorily. [[33]](#cite_note-Final_exams_at_the_Technical_University-33) [[34]](#cite_note-34) In suggested Steiner's name to Joseph Kürschner, chief editor of a new edition of Goethe's works, [[35]](#cite_note-35) who asked Steiner to become the edition's natural science editor, [[36]](#cite_note-36) a truly astonishing opportunity for a young student without any form of academic credentials or previous publications. [[37]](#cite_note-ZanderBio-37): 43 Before attending the Vienna Institute of Technology, Steiner had studied [Kant](/wiki/Immanuel_Kant), [Fichte](/wiki/Fichte) and [Schelling](/wiki/F._W._J._Schelling). [[11]](#cite_note-CorrDoc-11) Early spiritual experiences[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=3)] When he was nine years old, Steiner believed that he saw the spirit of an aunt who had died in a far-off town, asking him to help her at a time when neither he nor his family knew of the woman's death. [[38]](#cite_note-38) Steiner later related that as a child, he felt "that one must carry the knowledge of the spiritual world within oneself after the fashion of geometry ... [for here] one is permitted to know something which the mind alone, through its own power, experiences. In this feeling I found the justification for the spiritual world that I experienced ... I confirmed for myself by means of geometry the feeling that I must speak of a world 'which is not seen'." [[2]](#cite_note-Auto-2) Steiner believed that at the age of 15 he had gained a complete understanding of the concept of time, which he considered to be the precondition of spiritual [clairvoyance](/wiki/Clairvoyance). [[11]](#cite_note-CorrDoc-11) At 21, on the train between his home village and [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna), Steiner met an herb gatherer, Felix Kogutzki, who spoke about the spiritual world "as one who had his own experience therein". [[2]](#cite_note-Auto-2): 39-40 [[39]](#cite_note-39) Writer and philosopher[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=4)] In 1888, as a result of his work for the Kürschner edition of [Goethe](/wiki/Goethe)'s works, Steiner was invited to work as an editor at the Goethe archives in [Weimar](/wiki/Weimar). Steiner remained with the archive until 1896. It was a low-paid and boring job. [[13]](#cite_note-Cees-13) As well as the introductions for and commentaries to four volumes of Goethe's scientific writings, Steiner wrote two books about Goethe's philosophy: The Theory of Knowledge Implicit in Goethe's World-Conception (1886), [[40]](#cite_note-40) which Steiner regarded as the [epistemological](/wiki/Epistemological) foundation and justification for his later work, [[41]](#cite_note-41) and Goethe's Conception of the World (1897). [[42]](#cite_note-42) During this time he also collaborated in complete editions of the works of [Arthur Schopenhauer](/wiki/Arthur_Schopenhauer) and the writer [Jean Paul](/wiki/Jean_Paul) and wrote numerous articles for various journals. In 1891, Steiner received a doctorate in philosophy at the [University of Rostock](/wiki/University_of_Rostock), for his dissertation discussing [Fichte](/wiki/Johann_Gottlieb_Fichte)'s concept of the ego, [[25]](#cite_note-RAMcD-25) [[43]](#cite_note-43) submitted to [Heinrich von Stein](/w/index.php?title=Heinrich_von_Stein&action=edit&redlink=1), Steiner esteemed. [[2]](#cite_note-Auto-2): [Chap. 14](http://wn.rsarchive.org/Books/GA028/TSoML/GA028_c14.html) Steiner's dissertation was later published in expanded form as Truth and Knowledge: Prelude to a Philosophy of Freedom, with a dedication to [Eduard von Hartmann](/wiki/Eduard_von_Hartmann). [[44]](#cite_note-44) Two years later, in 1894, he published Die Philosophie der Freiheit ( [The Philosophy of Freedom or The Philosophy of Spiritual Activity](/wiki/The_Philosophy_of_Freedom), the latter being Steiner's preferred English title), an exploration of [epistemology](/wiki/Epistemology) and ethics that suggested a way for humans to become spiritually free beings. Steiner hoped that the book "would gain him a professorship", but the book was not well received. [[13]](#cite_note-Cees-13) Steiner later spoke of this book as containing implicitly, in philosophical form, the entire content of what he later developed explicitly as [anthroposophy](/wiki/Anthroposophy). [[45]](#cite_note-45) In 1896, Steiner declined an offer from [Elisabeth Förster-Nietzsche](/wiki/Elisabeth_F%C3%B6rster-Nietzsche) to help organize the Nietzsche archive in [Naumburg](/wiki/Naumburg). Her brother, [Friedrich Nietzsche](/wiki/Friedrich_Nietzsche), time [non compos mentis](/wiki/Non_compos_mentis). into the presence of the [catatonic](/wiki/Catatonic) philosopher; Steiner, deeply moved, subsequently wrote the book Friedrich Nietzsche, Fighter for Freedom. [[46]](#cite_note-46) Steiner later related that: My first acquaintance with Nietzsche's writings belongs to the year 1889. Previous to that I had never read a line of his. Upon the substance of my ideas as these find expression in The Philosophy of Spiritual Activity, Nietzsche's thought had not the least influence....Nietzsche's ideas of the ' [eternal recurrence]' and of ' [Übermensch]' remained long in my mind. For in these was reflected that which a personality must feel concerning the evolution and essential being of humanity when this personality is kept back from grasping the spiritual world by the restricted thought in the philosophy of nature characterizing the end of the 19th century....What attracted me particularly was that one could read Nietzsche without coming upon anything which strove to make the reader a 'dependent' of 18] In 1897, Steiner left the [Weimar](/wiki/Weimar) archives and moved to Berlin. He became part owner of, chief editor of, and an active contributor to the literary journal Magazin für Literatur, where he hoped to find a readership sympathetic to his philosophy. Many subscribers were alienated by Steiner's unpopular support of [Émile Zola](/wiki/%C3%89mile_Zola) in the [Dreyfus Affair](/wiki/Dreyfus_Affair) [[47]](#cite_note-GL-47) and the journal lost more subscribers when Steiner published extracts from his correspondence with anarchist [John Henry Mackay](/wiki/John_Henry_Mackay). [[47]](#cite_note-GL-47) Dissatisfaction with his editorial style eventually led to his departure from the magazine. In 1899, Steiner married Anna Eunicke; the couple separated several years later. Anna died in 1911. [[27]](#cite_note-CL-27) Despite his fame as a teacher of esotericism, Steiner was culturally and academically isolated. [[48]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELeijenhorst20061088-48) Theosophical Society[ In 1899, Steiner published an article, "Goethe's Secret Revelation", discussing the esoteric nature of Goethe's fairy tale [The Green Snake and the Beautiful Lily](/wiki/The_Green_Snake_and_the_Beautiful_Lily). This article led to an invitation by the Count and Countess Brockdorff to speak to a gathering of [Theosophists](/wiki/Theosophy_(Blavatskian)) on the subject of Nietzsche. Steiner continued speaking regularly to the members of the [Theosophical Society](/wiki/Theosophical_Society_Adyar), becoming the head of its newly constituted German section in 1902 without ever formally joining the society. [[25]](#cite_note-RAMcD-25) [[49]](#cite_note-Ravagli-49) It was also in connection with this society that Steiner met and worked with [Marie von Sivers](/wiki/Marie_von_Sivers), who became his second wife in 1914. By 1904, Steiner was appointed by [Annie Besant](/wiki/Annie_Besant) to be leader of the Theosophical Esoteric Society for Germany and Austria. In 1904, Eliza, the wife of [Helmuth von Moltke the Younger](/wiki/Helmuth_von_Moltke_the_Younger), became one of his favourite scholars. [[50]](#cite_note-50) Through Eliza, Steiner met Helmuth, who served as the [Chief of the German General Staff](/wiki/German_General_Staff) from 1906 to 1914. [[51]](#cite_note-51) In contrast to mainstream Theosophy, Steiner sought to build a Western approach to spirituality based on the philosophical and mystical traditions of European culture. The German Section of the Theosophical Society grew rapidly under Steiner's leadership as he lectured throughout much of Europe on his [spiritual science](/wiki/Spiritual_science). During this period, Steiner maintained an original approach, replacing [Madame Blavatsky](/wiki/H._P._Blavatsky)'s terminology with his own, and basing his spiritual research and teachings upon the Western esoteric and philosophical tradition. This and other differences, in particular Steiner's vocal rejection of [Leadbeater](/wiki/C._W._Leadbeater) and [Besant](/wiki/Annie_Besant)'s claim that [Jiddu Krishnamurti](/wiki/Jiddu_Krishnamurti) was the vehicle of a new Maitreya, or world teacher, [[52]](#cite_note-52) led to a formal split in 1912-13, [[25]](#cite_note-RAMcD-25) when Steiner and the majority of members of the German section of the Theosophical Society broke off to form a new group, the [Anthroposophical Society](/wiki/Anthroposophical_Society). Steiner took the name "Anthroposophy" from the title of a work of the Austrian philosopher [Robert von Zimmermann](/wiki/Robert_von_Zimmermann), published in Vienna in 1856. [[53]](#cite_note-53) Despite his departure from the Theosophical Society, Steiner maintained his interest in Theosophy throughout his life. [[54]](#cite_note-RSLib-54) Anthroposophical Society and its cultural activities[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=6)] The [Anthroposophical Society](/wiki/Anthroposophical_Society) grew rapidly. Fueled by a need to find an artistic home for their yearly conferences, which included performances of plays written by [Edouard Schuré](/wiki/Edouard_Schur%C3%A9) and Steiner, the decision was made to build a theater and organizational center. In 1913, construction began on the first [Goetheanum](/wiki/Goetheanum) building, in [Dornach](/wiki/Dornach), Switzerland. The building, designed by Steiner, was built to a significant part by volunteers. Steiner moved from [Berlin](/wiki/Berlin) [[55]](#cite_note-Berlin-55) to [Dornach](/wiki/Dornach) in 1913 and lived there to the end of his life. [[56]](#cite_note-HausHansi-56) Steiner's lecture activity expanded enormously with the end of the war. Most importantly, from 1919 on Steiner began to work with other members of the society to found numerous [practical institutions and activities](#Breadth_of_activity), including the first [Waldorf school](/wiki/Waldorf_schools), founded that year in [Stuttgart](/wiki/Stuttgart), Germany. On New Year's Eve, 1922-1923, the Goetheanum burned to the ground; contemporary police reports indicate arson as the probable cause. [[27]](#cite_note-CL-27): 752 [[57]](#cite_note-GA259-57): 796 Steiner immediately began work designing a [second Goetheanum](/wiki/Goetheanum) building - this time made of concrete instead of wood - which was completed in 1928, three years after his death. At a "Foundation Meeting" for members held at the Dornach center during Christmas 1923, Steiner founded the School of Spiritual Science. [[58]](#cite_note-58) This school, which was led by Steiner, initially had sections for general anthroposophy, [education](/wiki/Waldorf_education), [medicine](/wiki/Anthroposophical_medicine), performing arts ( [eurythmy](/wiki/Eurythmy), speech, drama and music), the literary arts and humanities, mathematics, astronomy, science, and visual arts. Later sections were added for the social sciences, youth and agriculture. [[59]](#cite_note-GoethRestruct-59) [[60]](#cite_note-60) [[61]](#cite_note-wn.rsarchive.org-61) The School of Spiritual Science included [meditative exercises given by Steiner](/wiki/Rudolf_Steiner%27s_exercises_for_spiritual_development). [ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=7)] Steiner became a well-known and controversial public figure during and after World War I. In response to the catastrophic situation in post-war Germany, he proposed extensive social reforms through the establishment of a [Threefold Social Order](/wiki/Threefold_Social_Order) in which the cultural, political and economic realms would be largely independent. Steiner argued that a fusion of the three realms had created the inflexibility that had led to catastrophes such as [World War I](/wiki/First_World_War). In connection with this, he promoted a radical solution in the disputed area of [Upper Silesia](/wiki/Upper_Silesia), claimed by both Poland and Germany. His suggestion that this area be granted at least provisional independence led to his being publicly accused of being a traitor to Germany. [[62]](#cite_note-62) Steiner opposed [Wilson](/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson)'s proposal to create new European nations based around ethnic groups, which he saw as opening the door to rampant nationalism. Steiner proposed, as an alternative: 'social territories' with democratic institutions that were accessible to all inhabitants of a territory whatever their origin while the needs of the various ethnicities would be met by independent cultural institutions. [[63]] Attacks, illness, and death[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=8)] The [National Socialist German Workers Party](/wiki/National_Socialist_German_Workers_Party) gained strength in Germany after the First World War. In 1919, a political theorist of this movement, [Dietrich Eckart](/wiki/Dietrich_Eckart), attacked Steiner and suggested that he was a Jew. [[64]](#cite_note-Werner-64) In 1921, [Adolf Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler) attacked Steiner on many fronts, including accusations that he was a tool of the Jews, [[65]](#cite_note-65) while other nationalist extremists in Germany called for a "war against Steiner". That same year, Steiner warned against the disastrous effects it would have for Central Europe if the National Socialists came to power. [[64]](#cite_note-Werner-64): 8 In 1922 a lecture Steiner was giving in Munich was disrupted when stink bombs were let off and the lights switched out, while people rushed the stage apparently attempting to attack Steiner, who exited safely through a back door. [[66]](#cite_note-66) [[67]](#cite_note-67) Unable to guarantee his safety, Steiner's agents cancelled his next lecture tour. [[47]](#cite_note-GL-47): 193 [[68]](#cite_note-68) The 1923 [Beer Hall Putsch](/wiki/Beer_Hall_Putsch) in Munich led Steiner to give up his residence in Berlin, saying that if those responsible for the attempted coup ( [Hitler](/wiki/Hitler)'s [Nazi](/wiki/Nazi) party) came to power in Germany, it would no longer be possible for him to enter the country. [[69]](#cite_note-69) From 1923 on, Steiner showed signs of increasing frailness and illness. He nonetheless continued to lecture widely, and even to travel; especially towards the end of this time, he was often giving two, three or even four lectures daily for courses taking place concurrently. Many of these lectures focused on practical areas of life such as education. [[70]](#cite_note-ReferenceA-70) Increasingly ill, he held his last lecture in late September, 1924. He continued work on his autobiography during the last months of his life; he died at Dornach on 30 March 1925. Steiner's ideas and the Nazi party[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=9)] Steiner financed the publication of and wrote a foreword for the book Die Entente-Freimaurerei und der Weltkrieg (1919) by [Karl Heise](/w/index.php?title=Karl_Heise&action=edit&redlink=1), partly based upon his own ideas. The publication comprised a [conspiracy theory](/wiki/Conspiracy_theory) according to which World War I was a consequence of a collusion of [Freemasons](/wiki/Freemasonry) and [Jews](/wiki/Jews) their purpose being the destruction of Germany. The writing was later enthusiastically received by the Nazi Party. [[71]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZander2007306,_991-992-71) [[72]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStaudenmaier201496-97-72) [Dick Taverne](/wiki/Dick_Taverne) claims that Steiner was a Nazi (i.e. a member of the NSDAP), but gives no evidence for this, and no other source confirms this. [[73]](#cite_note-Taverne_2006_p._28-73) Towards the end of Steiner's life and after his death, there were massive defamatory press attacks mounted on him by early [Nazi Party](/wiki/National_Socialist_German_Workers_Party) leaders (including [Adolf Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler)) and other right-wing nationalists. These criticized Steiner's thought and anthroposophy as being incompatible with Nazi racial ideology, and charged him with being influenced by his close connections with Jews and even (falsely) that he himself was Jewish. [[64]](#cite_note-Werner-64) [[74]](#cite_note-HuH-74) After Steiner's death, anthroposophy had both enemies and loyal supporters in the upper echelons of the Nazi regime. [[75]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStaudenmaier2014118-119-75) Staudenmaier speaks of the "polycratic party-state apparatus", so Nazism's approach to Anthroposophy was not characterized by monolithic ideological unity. [[76]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStaudenmaier2014104-76) [Rudolf Hess](/wiki/Rudolf_Hess), the adjunct Führer, was a patron [[77]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStaudenmaier2014214-77) [[78]](#cite_note-Rieppel_2016_p._246-78) and of Waldorf schools [[78]](#cite_note-Rieppel_2016_p._246-78) staunch defender of Steiner's [biodynamic agriculture](/wiki/Biodynamic_agriculture). [[80]](#cite_note-Tucker_2018_p._165-80) When Hess defected to UK, their most powerful protector was gone, [[78]](#cite_note-Rieppel_2016_p._246-78) [[79]](#cite_note-Douglas-Hamilton_2012_p._106-79) [[80]](#cite_note-Tucker_2018_p._165-80) but Anthroposophists were still not left without supporters among higher-placed Nazis. [[81]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStaudenmaier2014103-106-81) According to [Tommy Wieringa](/wiki/Tommy_Wieringa), a Dutch writer who grew among Anthroposophists, commenting upon an essay by the Anthroposophist [Désanne van Brederode](/w/index.php?title=D%C3%A9sanne_van_Brederode&action=edit&redlink=1), Hess and [Heinrich Himmler](/wiki/Heinrich_Himmler) saw Steiner as their kindred spirit. [[82]](#cite_note-NRC_2021-82) [[83]](#cite_note-Brederode_2021-83) The Third Reich had banned almost all esoteric organizations, pretending that these are controlled by Jews. [[84]](#cite_note-Sutin_2014_p._506-84) The truth was that while Anthroposophists complained of bad press, they were to a surprising extent let be by the Nazi regime, "including outspokenly supportive pieces in the Völkischer Beobachter". [[85]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStaudenmaier2014174-85) Ideological purists from [Sicherheitsdienst](/wiki/Sicherheitsdienst) argued largely in vain against Anthroposophy. [[85]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStaudenmaier2014174-85) According to Staudenmaier, "The prospect of unmitigated persecution was held at bay for years in a tenuous truce between pro-anthroposophical and anti-anthroposophical Nazi and Albert Steffen, had publicly expressed sympathy for the Nazi regime since its beginnings; led by such sympathies of their leadership, the Swiss and German Anthroposophical organizations chose for a path conflating accommodation with collaboration, which in the end ensured that while the Nazi regime hunted the esoteric organizations, Gentile Anthroposophists from Nazi Germany and countries occupied by it were let be to a surprising extent. [[81]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStaudenmaier2014103-106-81) Of course they had some setbacks from the enemies of Anthroposophy among the upper echelons of the Nazi regime, but Anthroposophists also had loyal supporters among them, so overall Gentile Anthroposophists were not badly hit by the Nazi regime. [[81]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStaudenmaier2014103-106-81) Spiritual research[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=10)] Steiner first began speaking publicly about spiritual experiences and phenomena in his 1899 lectures to the Theosophical Society. By 1901 he had begun to write about spiritual topics, initially in the form of discussions of historical figures such as the [mystics](/wiki/Mysticism) of the [Middle Ages](/wiki/Middle_Ages). By 1904 he was expressing his own understanding of these themes in his essays and books, while continuing to refer to a wide variety of historical sources. A world of spiritual perception is discussed in a number of writings which I have published since this book appeared. The Philosophy of Freedom forms the philosophical basis for these later writings. For it tries to show that the experience of thinking, rightly understood, is in fact an experience of spirit. (Steiner, Philosophy of Freedom, Consequences of Monism) Steiner aimed to apply his training in [mathematics](/wiki/Mathematics), science, and philosophy to produce rigorous, verifiable presentations of those experiences. [[86]](#cite_note-86) He believed that through freely chosen [ethical](/wiki/Ethics) disciplines and [meditative training](/wiki/Meditation), anyone could develop the ability to experience the spiritual world, including the higher nature of oneself and others. [[47]](#cite_note-GL-47) Steiner believed that such [discipline](/wiki/Discipline) and training would help a person to become a more [moral](/wiki/Morality), [creative](/wiki/Creativity) and [free](/wiki/Freedom_(philosophy)) [individual](/wiki/Individuality) - free in the sense of being capable of actions motivated solely by love. [[87]](#cite_note-Schneider-87) His philosophical ideas were affected by [Franz Brentano](/wiki/Franz_Brentano), [[47]](#cite_note-GL-47) with whom he had studied, [[88]](#cite_note-88) as by Fichte, [Geisteswissenschaft](/wiki/Geisteswissenschaft) (from Geist = mind or spirit, Wissenschaft = science), a term originally coined by [Wilhelm Dilthey](/wiki/Wilhelm_Dilthey) as a descriptor of the [humanities](/wiki/Humanities), in a novel way, to describe a systematic ("scientific") approach to spirituality. [[91]](#cite_note-91) Steiner used the term Geisteswissenschaft, generally translated into English as "spiritual science," to describe a discipline treating the spirit as something actual and real, starting from the premise that it is possible for human beings to penetrate behind what is sense-perceptible. [[92]](#cite_note-92) He proposed that psychology, history, and the humanities generally were based on the direct grasp of an ideal reality, [[93]](#cite_note-93) and required close attention to the particular period and culture which provided the distinctive character of religious qualities in the course of the evolution of consciousness. In contrast to William James' pragmatic approach to religious and psychic experience, which emphasized its idiosyncratic character, Steiner focused on ways such experience can be rendered more intelligible and integrated into human life. [[94]](#cite_note-94) Steiner proposed that an understanding of reincarnation and karma was necessary to understand psychology [[95]](#cite_note-95) and that the form of external nature would be more comprehensible as a result of insight into the course of karma in the evolution of humanity. [[96]](#cite_note-96) Beginning in 1910, he described aspects of karma relating to health, natural phenomena and free will, taking the position that a person is not bound by his or her karma, but can transcend this through actively taking hold of one's own nature and destiny. [[97]](#cite_note-97) In an extensive series of lectures from February to September 1924, Steiner presented further research on successive reincarnations of various individuals and described the techniques he used for karma research. [[70]](#cite_note-ReferenceA-70) [[98]](#cite_note-98) Breadth of activity[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=11)] After the First World War, Steiner became active in a wide variety of cultural contexts. He founded a number of schools, the first of which was known as the [Waldorf school](/wiki/Waldorf_education), [[99]](#cite_note-99) which later evolved into a worldwide school network. He also founded a system of organic agriculture, now known as [biodynamic agriculture](/wiki/Biodynamic_agriculture), which was one of the first forms of modern [organic farming](/wiki/Organic_farming). [[100]](#cite_note-100) His [work in medicine](/wiki/Anthroposophic_medicine) is based in [pseudoscience](/wiki/Pseudoscience) and occult ideas. Even though his medical ideas led to the development of a broad range of complementary medications and supportive artistic and biographic therapies, [[101]](#cite_note-101) they are considered ineffective by the medical community. [[102]](#cite_note-krit-102) Numerous homes for children and adults with [developmental disabilities](/wiki/Developmental_disabilities) based on his work (including those of the [Camphill movement](/wiki/Camphill_movement)) are found in Africa, Europe, and North America. [[103]](#cite_note-103) His paintings and drawings influenced [Joseph Beuys](/wiki/Joseph_Beuys) and other modern artists. His two [Goetheanum](/wiki/Goetheanum) buildings are considered significant examples of [[106]](#cite_note-106) [[107]](#cite_note-107) [[108]](#cite_note-108) and other anthroposophical architects have contributed thousands of buildings to the modern scene. [[109]](#cite_note-109) Steiner's [literary estate](/wiki/Literary_estate) is broad. Steiner's writings, published in volumes, include books, essays, [four plays](/wiki/Rudolf_Steiner%27s_Mystery_Dramas) ('mystery dramas'), mantric verse, and an autobiography. His collected lectures, making up another approximately 300 volumes, discuss a wide range of themes. Steiner's drawings, chiefly illustrations done on blackboards during his lectures, are collected in a separate series of 28 volumes. Many publications have covered his architectural legacy and sculptural work. [[110]](#cite_note-Biesantz-110) [[111]](#cite_note-Kugler-111) Education[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=12)] As a young man, Steiner was a private tutor and a lecturer on history for the Berlin Arbeiterbildungsschule, [[112]](#cite_note-zander2007-112) an educational initiative for working class adults. [[113]](#cite_note-njacobs-113) Soon thereafter, he began to articulate his ideas on education in public lectures, [[114]](#cite_note-Ullrich-114) culminating in a 1907 essay on The Education of the Child in which he described the major phases of child development which formed the foundation of his approach to education. [[115]](#cite_note-115) His [conception of education](/wiki/Definitions_of_education) was influenced by the [Herbartian](/wiki/Johann_Friedrich_Herbart) pedagogy prominent in Europe during the late nineteenth century, [[112]](#cite_note-zander2007-112): 1362, 1390ff [[114]](#cite_note-Ullrich-114) though Steiner criticized Herbart for not sufficiently recognizing the importance of educating the will and feelings as well as the intellect. [[116]](#cite_note-116) In 1919, [Emil Molt](/wiki/Emil_Molt) invited him to lecture to his workers at the Waldorf-Astoria cigarette factory in Stuttgart. Out of these lectures came the first Waldorf School. In 1922, Steiner presented these ideas at a conference called for this purpose in [Oxford](/wiki/Oxford) by Professor [Millicent Mackenzie](/wiki/Millicent_Mackenzie). He subsequently presented a teacher training course at [Torquay](/wiki/Torquay) in 1924 at an [Anthroposophy](/wiki/Anthroposophy) Summer School organised by [Eleanor Merry](/wiki/Eleanor_Merry). [[117]](#cite_note-Torquay-117) The Oxford Conference and the Torquay teacher training led to the founding of the first Waldorf schools in Britain. [[118]](#cite_note-118) During Steiner's lifetime, schools based on his educational principles were also founded in [Hamburg](/wiki/Hamburg), [Essen](/wiki/Essen), [The Hague](/wiki/The_Hague) and London; there schools](/wiki/Waldorf_education) worldwide. Biodynamic agriculture[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=13)] In 1924, a group of farmers concerned about the future of agriculture requested Steiner's help. Steiner responded with a lecture series on an [ecological](/wiki/Ecological_agriculture) and [sustainable](/wiki/Sustainable_agriculture) approach to agriculture that increased soil fertility without the use of [chemical fertilizers](/wiki/Chemical_fertilizer) and [pesticides](/wiki/Pesticide). [[28]](#cite_note-BD1924-28) Steiner's agricultural ideas promptly spread and were put into practice internationally [[119]](#cite_note-119) and [biodynamic agriculture](/wiki/Biodynamic_agriculture) is now practiced in Europe, [[120]](#cite_note-olympiad-120) North America, South America, [[121]](#cite_note-121) Africa, [[122]](#cite_note-122) Asia [[120]](#cite_note-olympiad-120) [Australasia](/wiki/Australasia). [[123]](#cite_note-Koberwitz-123) [[124]](#cite_note-124) [[125]](#cite_note-125) A central aspect of biodynamics is that the farm as a whole is seen as an organism, and therefore should be a largely self-sustaining system, producing its own [manure](/wiki/Manure) and [animal feed](/wiki/Fodder). Plant or animal disease is seen as a symptom of problems in the whole organism. Steiner also suggested timing such agricultural activities as sowing, weeding, and harvesting to utilize the influences on plant growth of the [moon](/wiki/Moon) and [planets](/wiki/Planets); and the application of natural materials prepared in specific ways to the [soil](/wiki/Soil), [compost](/wiki/Composting), and crops, with the intention of engaging non-physical beings and elemental forces.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] He encouraged his listeners to verify such suggestions [empirically](/wiki/Scientific_method), as he had not yet done. [[123]](#cite_note-Koberwitz-123) In a 2002 newspaper editorial, Peter Treue, agricultural researcher at the [University of Kiel](/wiki/University_of_Kiel), characterized biodynamics as [pseudoscience](/wiki/Pseudoscience) and argued that similar or equal results can be obtained using standard organic farming principles. He wrote that some biodynamic preparations more resemble [alchemy](/wiki/Alchemy) or [magic](/wiki/Magic_(paranormal)) akin the late 1910s, Steiner was working with doctors to create a [new approach to medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine). In 1921, [pharmacists](/wiki/Pharmacist) and physicians gathered under Steiner's guidance to create a pharmaceutical company called [Weleda](/wiki/Weleda) which now distributes naturopathic medical and beauty products worldwide. At around the same time, Dr. [Ita Wegman](/wiki/Ita_Wegman) founded a first anthroposophic medical clinic (now the Ita Wegman Clinic) in [Arlesheim](/wiki/Arlesheim). Anthroposophic medicine is practiced in some 80 countries. [[127]](#cite_note-127) It is a form of [alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) based on [pseudoscientific](/wiki/Pseudoscience) and [occult](/wiki/Occult) notions. [[128]](#cite_note-teils-128) Social reform[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=15)] For a period after World War I, Steiner was active as a lecturer on social reform. A petition expressing his basic social ideas was widely circulated and signed by many cultural figures of the day, including [Hermann Hesse](/wiki/Hermann_Hesse). In Steiner's chief book on [social reform](/wiki/Social_reform), Toward Social Renewal, he suggested that the cultural, political and economic spheres of society need to work together as consciously cooperating yet independent entities, each with a particular task: political institutions should be democratic, establish [political equality](/wiki/Equality_before_the_law) and protect [human rights](/wiki/Human_rights); cultural institutions should nurture the free and unhindered development of science, art, education and religion; and economic institutions should enable producers, distributors, and consumers to cooperate voluntarily to provide efficiently for society's needs. [[129]](#cite_note-Essential-129) He saw this division of responsibility as a vital task which would take up consciously the historical trend toward the mutual independence of these three realms. Steiner also gave suggestions for many specific social reforms. Steiner proposed that societal well-being fundamentally depends upon a relationship of mutuality between the individuals and the community as a whole: The well-being of a community of people working together will be the greater, the less the individual claims for himself the proceeds of his work, i.e. the more of these proceeds he makes over to his fellow-workers, the more his own needs are satisfied, not out of his own work but out of the work done by others.— Steiner, The Fundamental Social Law [[130]] He expressed another aspect of this in the following motto: The healthy social life is found When in the mirror of each human soul The whole community finds its reflection, And when in the community The virtue of each one is living.— Steiner, The Fundamental Social Law [[130]] Architecture and visual arts[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=16)] Steiner designed 17 buildings, including the [First and Second Goetheanums](/wiki/Goetheanum). [[131]](#cite_note-131) These two buildings, built in Dornach, Switzerland, were intended to house significant theater spaces as well as a "school for spiritual science". [[132]](#cite_note-132) Three of Steiner's buildings have been listed amongst the most significant works of modern architecture. [[133]](#cite_note-133) His primary sculptural work is The Representative of Humanity (1922), a nine-meter high wood sculpture executed as a joint project with the sculptor [Edith Maryon](/wiki/Edith_Maryon). This was intended to be placed in the first Goetheanum. It shows a central human figure, the "Representative of Humanity," holding a balance between opposing tendencies of expansion and contraction personified as the beings of [Lucifer](/wiki/Lucifer) and [Ahriman](/wiki/Ahriman). [[134]](#cite_note-134) [[135]](#cite_note-135) [[136]](#cite_note-136) It was intended to show, in conscious contrast to Michelangelo's [Last Judgment](/wiki/The_Last_Judgment_(Michelangelo)), Christ as mute and impersonal such that the beings that approach him must judge themselves. [[137]](#cite_note-137) The sculpture is now on permanent display at the Goetheanum. Steiner's blackboard drawings were unique at the time and almost certainly not originally intended as art works. [[138]](#cite_note-138) [Joseph Beuys](/wiki/Joseph_Beuys)' work, itself heavily influenced by Steiner, has led to the modern understanding of Steiner's drawings as artistic objects. [[139]](#cite_note-139) Performing arts[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=17)] Steiner wrote four [mystery plays](/wiki/Mystery_plays) between 1909 and 1913: The Portal of Initiation, The Souls' Probation, The Guardian of the Threshold and The Soul's Awakening, modeled on the esoteric dramas of [Edouard Maeterlinck](/wiki/Maurice_Maeterlinck), and [Johann Wolfgang von plays continue to be performed by anthroposophical groups in various countries, most notably (in the original German) in Dornach, Switzerland and (in English translation) in Spring Valley, New York and in Stroud and Stourbridge in the U.K. In collaboration with Marie von Sivers, Steiner also founded a new approach to acting, storytelling, and the recitation of poetry. His last public lecture course, given in 1924, was on speech and drama. The Russian actor, director, and acting coach [Michael Chekhov](/wiki/Michael_Chekhov) based significant aspects of his method of acting on Steiner's work. [[141]](#cite_note-141) [[142]](#cite_note-142) Together with [Marie von Sivers](/wiki/Marie_von_Sivers), Rudolf Steiner also developed the art of [eurythmy](/wiki/Eurythmy), sometimes referred to as "visible speech and song". According to the principles of eurythmy, there are archetypal movements or gestures that correspond to every aspect of speech - the sounds (or [phonemes](/wiki/Phonemes)), the rhythms, and the grammatical function - to every "soul quality" - joy, despair, tenderness, etc. - and to every aspect of music - tones, intervals, rhythms, and harmonies. Esoteric schools[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=18)] Steiner was founder and leader of the following: - His independent Esoteric School of the Theosophical Society, founded in 1904. This school continued after the break with [Theosophy](/wiki/Theosophy_(Blavatskian))but was disbanded at the start of World War I. - A lodge called Mystica Aeterna within the [Masonic Order of Memphis and Mizraim](/wiki/Ancient_and_Primitive_Rite), which Steiner led from 1906 until around 1914. Steiner added to the Masonic rite a number of Rosicrucian references. [[143]](#cite_note-143) - The School of Spiritual Science of the Anthroposophical Society, founded in 1923 as a further development of his earlier Esoteric School. This was originally constituted with a general section and seven specialized sections for education, literature, performing arts, natural sciences, medicine, visual arts, and astronomy. [[59]](#cite_note-GoethRestruct-59) [[61]](#cite_note-wn.rsarchive.org-61) [[144]](#cite_note-144)Steiner gave members of the School the first Lesson for guidance into the esoteric work in February 1924. [[145]](#cite_note-145)Though Steiner intended to develop three "classes" of this school, only the first of these was developed in his lifetime (and continues today). An authentic text of the written records on which the teaching of the First Class was based was published in 1992. [[146]](#cite_note-146) Philosophical ideas[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=19)] Goethean science[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=20)] In his written between 1884 and 1897, Steiner presented Goethe's approach to science as essentially [phenomenological](/wiki/Phenomenology_(philosophy)) in nature, rather than theory or model-based. He developed this conception further in several books, The Theory of Knowledge Implicit in Goethe's World-Conception (1886) and Goethe's Conception of the World (1897), particularly emphasizing the transformation in Goethe's approach from the physical sciences, where experiment played the primary role, to plant biology, where both accurate perception and imagination were required to find the biological archetypes (Urpflanze). He postulated that Goethe had sought, but been unable to fully find, the further transformation in scientific thinking necessary to properly interpret and understand the animal kingdom. [[147]](#cite_note-Hemleben-147) Steiner emphasized the role of evolutionary thinking in Goethe's discovery of the [intermaxillary bone](/wiki/Intermaxillary_segment) in human beings; Goethe expected human anatomy to be an evolutionary transformation of animal anatomy. [[147]](#cite_note-Hemleben-147) Steiner defended [Goethe's qualitative description of color](/wiki/Goethe%27s_theory_of_color) as arising synthetically from the polarity of light and darkness, in contrast to [Newton](/wiki/Isaac_Newton)'s particle-based and analytic conception. Particular organic forms can be evolved only from universal types, and every organic entity we experience must coincide with some one of these derivative forms of the type. Here the evolutionary method must replace the method of proof. We aim not to show that external conditions act upon one another in a certain way and thereby bring about a definite result, but that a particular form has developed under definite external conditions out of the type. This is the radical difference between inorganic and organic science.— Rudolf Steiner, The Theory of Knowledge Implicit in Goethe's World Conception, Chapter XVI, "Organic Nature" A variety of authors have termed Goethean [[148]](#cite_note-Storr-Einstein-148) [[149]](#cite_note-FlynnDawkins2007-149) [[150]](#cite_note-Shermer_Linse_2002_p._32-150) According to Dan following that the [motions of the planets](/wiki/Celestial_mechanics)were caused by the relationships of the spiritual beings that inhabited them"; [[150]](#cite_note-Shermer_Linse_2002_p._32-150) [vitalism](/wiki/Vitalism); [[150]](#cite_note-Shermer_Linse_2002_p._32-150) - doubting [germ theory](/wiki/Germ_theory); [[150]](#cite_note-Shermer_Linse_2002_p._32-150) - non-standard approach to physiological systems, including claiming that the heart is not a pump. [[149]](#cite_note-FlynnDawkins2007-149) Knowledge and freedom[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=21)] Steiner approached the philosophical questions of [knowledge](/wiki/Epistemology) and [freedom](/wiki/Free_will) in two stages. In his dissertation, published in expanded form in 1892 as Truth and Knowledge, Steiner suggests that there is an inconsistency between Kant's philosophy, which posits that all knowledge is a representation of an essential verity inaccessible to human consciousness, and modern science, which assumes that all influences can be found in the sensory and mental world to which we have access. Steiner considered Kant's philosophy of an inaccessible beyond ("Jenseits-Philosophy") a stumbling block in achieving a satisfying philosophical viewpoint. [[152]](#cite_note-152) Steiner postulates that the world is essentially an indivisible unity, but that our [consciousness](/wiki/Consciousness) divides it into the [sense](/wiki/Senses)-perceptible appearance, on the one hand, and the formal nature accessible to our [thinking](/wiki/Thinking), on the other. He sees in thinking itself an element that can be strengthened and deepened sufficiently to penetrate all that our senses do not reveal to us. Steiner thus considered what appears to human experience as a division between the spiritual and natural worlds to be a conditioned result of the structure of our consciousness, which separates [perception](/wiki/Perception) and thinking. These two faculties give us not two worlds, but two complementary views of the same world; neither has primacy and the two together are necessary and sufficient to arrive at a complete understanding of the world. In thinking about [perception](/wiki/Perception) (the path of natural science) and perceiving the process of thinking (the path of [spiritual](/wiki/Spirituality) training), it is possible to discover a hidden inner unity between the two poles of our experience. [[87]](#cite_note-Schneider-87): Chapter 4 [Truth](/wiki/Truth), for Steiner, is paradoxically both an objective discovery and yet "a free creation of the human spirit, that never would exist at all if we did not generate it ourselves. The task of understanding is not to replicate in conceptual form something that already exists, but rather to create a wholly new realm, that together with the world given to our senses constitutes the fullness of reality." [[153]](#cite_note-153) In [The Philosophy of Freedom](/wiki/The_Philosophy_of_Freedom), Steiner further explores potentials within thinking: freedom, he suggests, can only be approached gradually with the aid of the creative activity of thinking. Thinking can be a free deed; in addition, it can liberate our will from its subservience to our [instincts](/wiki/Instinct) and [drives](/wiki/Motivation). Free deeds, he suggests, are those for which we are fully conscious of the motive for our action; freedom is the spiritual activity of penetrating with consciousness our own nature and that of the world, [[154]](#cite_note-154) and the real activity of acting in full consciousness. [[87]](#cite_note-Schneider-87): 133-4 This includes overcoming influences of both heredity and environment: "To be free is to be capable of thinking one's own thoughts - not the thoughts merely of the body, or of society, but thoughts generated by one's deepest, most original, most essential and spiritual self, one's individuality." [[25]](#cite_note-RAMcD-25) Steiner affirms [Darwin](/wiki/Charles_Darwin)'s and [Haeckel](/wiki/Haeckel)'s [evolutionary](/wiki/Evolution) perspectives but this beyond its [materialistic](/wiki/Materialism) consequences; he sees human [consciousness](/wiki/Consciousness), indeed, all human culture, as a product of natural evolution that transcends itself. For Steiner, nature becomes self-conscious in the human being. Steiner's description of the nature of human consciousness thus closely parallels that of [Solovyov](/wiki/Vladimir_Solovyov_(philosopher)). [[155]](#cite_note-155) Spiritual science[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=22)] In his earliest works, Steiner already spoke of the "natural and spiritual worlds" as a unity. [[47]](#cite_note-GL-47) From 1900 on, he began lecturing about concrete details of the spiritual world(s), culminating in the publication in 1904 of the first of several systematic presentations, his Theosophy: An Introduction to the Spiritual Processes in Human Life and in the Cosmos. As a starting point for the book Steiner took a quotation from Goethe, describing the method of natural scientific observation, [[156]](#cite_note-156) while in the Preface he made clear that the line of thought taken in this book led to the same goal as that in his earlier work, The Philosophy of Freedom. [[157]](#cite_note-157) In the years 1903-1908 Steiner maintained the magazine Lucifer-Gnosis and published in it essays on topics such as initiation, reincarnation and karma, and knowledge of the supernatural world. [[158]](#cite_note-158) Some of these were later collected and published as books, such as How to Know Higher Worlds (1904-5) and Cosmic Memory. The book An Outline of Esoteric Science was published in 1910. Important themes include: - the human being as body, [soul](/wiki/Soul_(spirit))and [spirit](/wiki/Vitalism); - the path of spiritual development; - spiritual influences on world-evolution and history; and [reincarnation](/wiki/Reincarnation)and [karma](/wiki/Karma). Steiner emphasized that there is an objective natural and spiritual world that can be known, and that perceptions of the spiritual world and incorporeal beings are, under conditions of training comparable to that required for the natural sciences, including self-discipline, replicable by multiple observers. It is on this basis that [spiritual science](/wiki/Spiritual_science) is possible, with radically different epistemological foundations than those of natural science. He believed that natural science was correct in its methods but one-sided for exclusively focusing on sensory phenomena, while mysticism was vague in its methods, though seeking to explore the inner and spiritual life. Anthroposophy was meant to apply the systematic methods of the former to the content of the latter [[159]](#cite_note-159) [[160]](#cite_note-160) For Steiner, the cosmos is permeated and continually transformed by the creative activity of non-physical processes and spiritual beings. For the human being to become conscious of the objective reality of these processes and beings, it is necessary to creatively enact and reenact, within, their creative activity. Thus objective spiritual knowledge always entails creative inner activity. [[47]](#cite_note-GL-47) Steiner articulated three stages of any creative deed: [[87]](#cite_note-Schneider-87): Pt II, Chapter 1 - Moral intuition: the ability to discover or, preferably, develop valid ethical principles; - Moral imagination: the imaginative transformation of such principles into a concrete intention applicable to the particular situation ( [situational ethics](/wiki/Situational_ethics)); and - Moral technique: the realization of the intended transformation, depending on a mastery of practical skills. Steiner termed his work from this period onwards [Anthroposophy](/wiki/Anthroposophy). He emphasized that the spiritual path he articulated builds upon and supports individual freedom and independent [judgment](/wiki/Judgment); for the results of spiritual research to be appropriately presented in a modern context they must be in a form accessible to [logical](/wiki/Logic) understanding, so that those who do not have access to the spiritual experiences underlying anthroposophical research can make independent evaluations of the latter's results. [[87]](#cite_note-Schneider-87) Spiritual training is to support what Steiner considered the overall purpose of human evolution, the development of the mutually interdependent qualities of love and [freedom](/wiki/Free_will). [[25]](#cite_note-RAMcD-25) Steiner and Christianity[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=23)] Steiner appreciated the ritual of the mass he experienced while serving as an altar boy from school age until he was ten years old, and this experience remained memorable for him as a genuinely spiritual one, contrasting with his irreligious family life. [[161]](#cite_note-Steiner_1982_pp._31-32-161) As a young adult, Steiner had no formal connection to organized religion. In 1899, he experienced what he described as a life-transforming inner encounter with the being of Christ. Steiner was then 38, and the experience of meeting Christ occurred after a tremendous inner struggle. To use Steiner's own words, the "experience culminated in my standing in the spiritual presence of the Mystery of [Golgotha](/wiki/Calvary) in a most profound and solemn festival of knowledge." [[162]](#cite_note-162) His relationship to Christianity thereafter remained entirely founded upon personal experience, and thus both non-denominational and strikingly different from conventional religious forms. [[25]](#cite_note-RAMcD-25) Christ and human evolution[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=24)] Steiner describes Christ as the unique pivot and meaning of earth's evolutionary processes and human history, redeeming [the Fall](/wiki/The_Fall_of_Man) from [Paradise](/wiki/Paradise). [[163]](#cite_note-Willmann-163) He understood the Christ as a being that unifies and inspires all religions, not belonging to a particular religious faith. To be "Christian" is, for Steiner, a search for balance between polarizing extremes [[163]](#cite_note-Willmann-163): 102-3 and the ability to manifest love in freedom. [[25]](#cite_note-RAMcD-25) Central principles of his understanding include: - The being of Christ is central to all religions, though called by different names by each. - Every religion is valid and true for the time and cultural context in which it was born. - Historical forms of Christianity need to be transformed in our times in order to meet the ongoing evolution of humanity. In Steiner's [esoteric cosmology](/wiki/Esoteric_cosmology), the spiritual development of humanity is interwoven in and inseparable from the cosmological development of the universe. Continuing the evolution that led to humanity being born out of the natural world, the Christ being brings an impulse enabling human consciousness of the forces that act creatively, but unconsciously, in nature. [[164]](#cite_note-164) Divergence from conventional Christian thought[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=25)] Steiner's views of Christianity diverge from conventional Christian thought in key places, and include [gnostic](/wiki/Gnostic) elements. [[147]](#cite_note-Hemleben-147) However, unlike many gnostics, Steiner affirms the unique and actual physical Incarnation of Christ in Jesus at the beginning of the Christian era. One of the central points of divergence with conventional Christian thought is found in [Steiner's views on reincarnation and karma](/wiki/Anthroposophy#Nature_of_the_human_being). Steiner also posited two different Jesus children involved in the Incarnation of the Christ: one child descended from [Solomon](/wiki/Solomon), as described in the [Gospel of Matthew](/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew); the other child from [Nathan](/wiki/Nathan_(son_of_David)), as described in the [Gospel of Luke](/wiki/Gospel_of_Luke). [[129]](#cite_note-Essential-129) He references in this regard the fact that the [genealogies](/wiki/Genealogy) in these two gospels list twenty-six (Luke) to forty-one (Matthew) completely different ancestors for the generations from [David](/wiki/King_David) to Jesus. Steiner's view of the [second coming](/wiki/Second_coming) of Christ is also unusual. He suggested that this would not be a physical reappearance, but rather, meant that the Christ being would become manifest in non-physical form, in the " [etheric](/wiki/Etheric_plane) realm" - i.e. visible to spiritual vision and apparent in community life - for increasing numbers of people, beginning around the year 1933. He emphasized that the future would require humanity to recognize this Spirit of Love in all its genuine forms, regardless of how this is named. He also warned that the traditional name, "Christ", might be used, yet the true essence of this Being of Love ignored. [[147]](#cite_note-Hemleben-147) The Christian Community[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=26)] In the 1920s, Steiner was approached by [Friedrich Rittelmeyer](/wiki/Friedrich_Rittelmeyer), a [Lutheran](/wiki/Lutheran) pastor with a congregation in Berlin, who asked if it was possible to create a more modern form of Christianity. Soon others joined Rittelmeyer - mostly Protestant pastors and theology students, but including several Roman Catholic priests. Steiner offered counsel on renewing the spiritual potency of the sacraments while emphasizing [freedom of thought](/wiki/Freedom_of_thought) and a personal relationship to religious life. He envisioned a new synthesis of Catholic and Protestant approaches to religious life, terming this "modern, [Johannine Christianity](/wiki/John_the_Evangelist)". [[129]](#cite_note-Essential-129) The resulting movement for religious renewal became known as " [The Christian Community](/wiki/The_Christian_Community)". Its work is based on a free relationship to Christ without dogma or policies. Its priesthood, which is open to both men and women, is free to preach out of their own spiritual insights and creativity. Steiner emphasized that the resulting movement for the renewal of Christianity was a personal gesture of help to a movement founded by Rittelmeyer and others independently of his anthroposophical work. [[129]](#cite_note-Essential-129) The distinction was important to Steiner because he sought with Anthroposophy to create a scientific, not [faith](/wiki/Faith)-based, spirituality. [[163]](#cite_note-Willmann-163) He recognized that for those who wished to find more traditional forms, however, a renewal of the traditional religions was also a vital need of the times. Reception[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=27)] Steiner's work has influenced a broad range of notable personalities. These include: - philosophers critical of esoteric movements generally, terms Steiner "arguably the most historically and philosophically sophisticated spokesperson of the [Esoteric](/wiki/Esoteric) Tradition." [[185]](#cite_note-Hammer-185) [Albert Schweitzer](/wiki/Albert_Schweitzer) wrote that he and Steiner had in common that they had "taken on the life mission of working for the emergence of a true culture enlivened by the ideal of humanity and to encourage people to become truly thinking beings". [[186]](#cite_note-186) However, Schweitzer was not an adept of mysticism or occultism, but of [Age of Anthroposophy: "His belief system is so eccentric, so unsupported by evidence, so manifestly bizarre, that rational skeptics are bound to consider it delusional.... But, whereas Einstein's way of perceiving the world by thought became confirmed by experiment and mathematical proof, Steiner's remained intensely subjective and insusceptible of objective confirmation." [[148]](#cite_note-Storr-Einstein-148) [Robert Todd Carroll](/wiki/Robert_Todd_Carroll) has said of Steiner that "Some of his ideas on education - such as educating the handicapped in the mainstream - are worth considering, although his overall plan for developing the spirit and the soul rather than the intellect cannot be admired". [[196]](#cite_note-196) Race and ethnicity[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Rudolf_Steiner&action=edit§ion=30)] Steiner's work includes both universalist, humanist elements and racial assumptions. [[197]](#cite_note-Staud-197) Due to the contrast and even contradictions between these elements, one commentator argues: "whether a given reader interprets Anthroposophy as racist or not depends upon that reader's concerns". [[198]](#cite_note-Zander-198) Steiner considered that by dint of its shared language and culture, each people has a unique essence, which he called its soul or spirit. [[185]](#cite_note-Hammer-185) He saw race as a physical manifestation of humanity's spiritual evolution, and at times discussed race in terms of complex hierarchies that were largely derived from 19th century [biology](/wiki/Scientific_racism), [anthropology](/wiki/Historical_race_concepts), philosophy and [theosophy](/wiki/Theosophy_(Blavatskian)). However, he consistently and explicitly subordinated race, ethnicity, gender, and indeed all hereditary factors, to individual factors in development. [[198]](#cite_note-Zander-198) For Steiner, human individuality is centered in a person's unique biography, and he believed that an individual's experiences and development are not bound by a single lifetime or the qualities of the physical body. [[49]](#cite_note-Ravagli-49) Steiner occasionally characterized specific [races](/wiki/Race_(classification_of_human_beings)), nations and [ethnicities](/wiki/Ethnicity) in ways that have been deemed [racist](/wiki/Racist) by critics. [[199]](#cite_note-199) This includes descriptions by him of certain races and ethnic groups as flowering, others as backward, or destined to degenerate or disappear. [[198]](#cite_note-Zander-198) He presented explicitly hierarchical views of the spiritual evolution of different races, [[200]](#cite_note-200) including—at times, and inconsistently—portraying the [white race](/wiki/White_race), [European culture](/wiki/European_culture) or Germanic culture as representing the high point of human [evolution](/wiki/Evolution) as of the early 20th century, although he did describe them as destined to be superseded by future cultures. [[198]](#cite_note-Zander-198) Throughout his life Steiner consistently emphasized the core spiritual unity of all the world's peoples and sharply criticized racial prejudice. He articulated beliefs that the individual nature of any person stands higher than any racial, ethnic, national or religious affiliation. [[27]](#cite_note-CL-27) [[129]](#cite_note-Essential-129) His belief that race and [ethnicity](/wiki/Ethnicity) are transient and superficial, and not essential aspects of the individual, [[198]](#cite_note-Zander-198) was partly rooted in his conviction that each individual [reincarnates](/wiki/Reincarnation) in a variety of different peoples and races over successive lives, and that each of us thus bears within him or herself the heritage of many races and peoples. [[198]](#cite_note-Zander-198) [[201]](#cite_note-201) Toward the end of his life, Steiner predicted that race will rapidly lose any remaining significance for future generations. [[198]](#cite_note-Zander-198) In Steiner's view, culture is universal, and explicitly not ethnically based, and he vehemently criticized imperialism. [[202]](#cite_note-202) In the context of his ethical individualism, Steiner considered "race, folk, ethnicity and gender" to be general, describable categories into which individuals may choose to fit, but from which free human beings can and will liberate themselves. [[49]](#cite_note-Ravagli-49) The racism of Anthroposophy is spiritual and paternalistic (i.e. benevolent), while the racism of fascism is materialistic and often malign.
